article.description: Mike Sweetney scored 26 points and grabbed 11 rebounds to lead Georgetown past Providence 67-58 in the second round of the NIT Monday night.
article.headline: Hoyas roll into quarterfinal matchup vs. UNC
article.linkText: Sweetney shoots Hoyas past Friars in NIT
article.story: PROVIDENCE, R.I. (AP) -- Mike Sweetney's 26 points led Georgetown to a 67-58 win over Providence in the second round of the Owens Corning NIT Monday night. But the Hoyas pulled away with their top scorer on the bench. Sweetney sat down after committing his fourth foul with 14:22 left in the game. At the time, the Hoyas were up by three, 35-32. With Sweetney on the bench, Georgetown went on a 12-7 run, sparked by 3-pointers from Tony Bethel and Gerald Riley. By the time he returned with 6:22 to play, the Hoyas were leading 47-39. "I was scared to death when Mike went out,'' Coach Craig Esherick said. "Historically, when he goes out, we have trouble scoring.'' Ryan Gomes led Providence (18-14) with 21 points and a game-high 13 rebounds. Georgetown (17-14) now faces North Carolina in Chapel Hill in the tournament's third round on Wednesday. The Tar Heels beat Wyoming 90-74 on Monday night. Georgetown's defense shut down the Friars for much of the second half, holding them without a basket for 10 minutes. The Hoyas took a 62-49 lead on a Sweetney dunk with less than two minutes left. Bethel scored 18 points and Riley added 11 for Georgetown. Donnie McGrath and Rob Sanders added 10 points each for Providence. Georgetown held the Friars to 34.5 percent shooting from the field, including 3-of-20 from the 3-point line. The Friars were 15-of-26 from the foul line, despite being in the bonus for the last 12 minutes of the second half. The Hoyas, meanwhile, made 26-of-32 free throws, with Sweetney and Bethel sinking 10 each. The loss ends Providence's season. After an inconsistent early season, the Friars finished the season by winning eight of their last 11 games, including victories over Big East rivals Connecticut, Villanova and Seton Hall. "Tonight we just ran out of steam,'' Providence Coach Tim Welsh said. "We had a great run over the last month of the season ... the NIT was a great springboard for next season.''
